title: Asperula aristata
text:
Asperula aristata is a <a href="deciduous">deciduous</a> <a href="species">species</a> of perennial groundcover, and a <a href="flowering%20plant">flowering plant</a> in the family <a href="Rubiaceae">Rubiaceae</a>, known as Woodruff, and is endemic to <a href="Morocco">Morocco</a>, <a href="Libya">Libya</a>, <a href="Algeria">Algeria</a>, <a href="Tunisia">Tunisia</a>, <a href="Azerbaijan">Azerbaijan</a>, <a href="Georgia%20%28country%29">Georgia</a>, <a href="Armenia">Armenia</a>, <a href="Greece">Greece</a>, <a href="Bulgaria">Bulgaria</a>, <a href="Albania">Albania</a>, <a href="Serbia">Serbia</a>, <a href="North%20Macedonia">North Macedonia</a>, <a href="Croatia">Croatia</a>, <a href="Italy">Italy</a>, <a href="Austria">Austria</a>, <a href="Switzerland">Switzerland</a>, <a href="France">France</a>, <a href="Spain">Spain</a>, and <a href="Portugal">Portugal</a>.
Its synonym is "Asperula calabra"
Description.
"Asperula ambleia" appears as a long green plant, with small (1in) pale purple flowers, on long, thin, green stems, it has thin, green, grass-like leaves.
Growth cycle.
"Asperula ambleia" flowers around May-June, and grows best in a rock garden, trough or crevice.
